question: What is the purpose of the VERIFY command?
answer: To make certain that a program file was properly saved to disk.

question: What does the VERIFY command compare?
answer: Each character in the program against the equivalent character in the computer's memory.

question: What happens if the disk copy of the program differs from the copy in memory?
answer: VERIFY ERROR will be displayed, indicating that the copies differ.

question: Why is there no point in trying to VERIFY a disk copy of a program after the original is no longer in memory?
answer: Because there is nothing to compare to, an apparent error will always be announced, even though the disk copy is automatically verified as it is written to the diskette.

question: What is the format for the VERIFY command?
What does the 'drive#:' part of the VERIFY command format specify?
What does the 'pattern' part of the VERIFY command format specify?
answer: Any string expression that evaluates to a file name, with or without pattern-matching characters.

question: What does the 'device#' part of the VERIFY command format specify?
What does the 'relocate flag' part of the VERIFY command format specify?
answer: Whether the file will be verified where originally saved, rather than relocated into the BASIC text area.

question: What is an alternate form of the VERIFY command?
What does the alternate form of the VERIFY command do?
answer: Verifies the last files used without having to type its name or drive number.

question: Why won't the alternate form of the VERIFY command work properly after SAVE-WITH-REPLACE?
answer: Because the last file used was the one deleted, and the drive will try to compare the deleted file to the program in memory.

question: How can you use VERIFY after @SAVE?
answer: By including at least part of the file name that is to be verified in the pattern.

question: Why will VERIFY nearly always announce an error when verifying a relocated BASIC file?
answer: Due to changes in the link pointers of BASIC programs made during relocation.

question: Why is it best to VERIFY files saved from the same type of machine and identical memory size?
answer: Because a BASIC program saved from one machine can't be verified easily with another machine, even when the program would work fine on both machines.
